posts.com:
>>6367918
>Is artist grade Gouache worth it?
Yes. You'll get more pigment, smoother grind, better flow, single-pigment colours (better mixing), less fillers (more vibrant). Schmincke is great, and I can wholly recommend. Just get a few tubes of artist-grade instead of a bunch of chinesium.

>I also want to start painting with acrylic. Do it need any special medium like oil paint or just apply directly on canvas?
Water-soluble, so thinning with water works. You'll only need mediums if you want to thin it a ton, since super-thinned paint films are not necessarily durable. Other than that you can pretty much paint on anything. It's essentially coloured plastic.

There's like a million mediums that you won't need but that could be nice, like thickeners, thinners, drying time extenders, crackling, more shine, less shine, flow improvers, etc. You can make a frankenpaint to your specific liking if you really want to tinker with it.

>>6368450
As said in last thread, Mont Marte probably does not manufacture their own stuff and commission random (see: cheapest) manufacturer to make stuff they just repackage. Sometimes you can get decent stuff, but it really is playing art supply gacha.

HIMI Jelly Gouache is significantly better, and honestly a pretty decent quality paint. I would recommend Holbein, if that's available in your neck of the woods.

>>6368722
>unless you use W&N brand which has better pigments than other brands.
Holbein, WN, Schmincke Horadam, and M. Graham all make Gouache without the addition of whiteners, relying on pure pigment density to get opacity. Any of these will work. It's notable that Holbein is by far the cheapest, at least in EU, and Schmincke pigment is very finely ground so it's less opaque than the others.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6372118
chalk/marble dust (can extend pigments in oil; use for making paint transparent for glazing in oil; traditional glue chalk ground is less expensive than ready-made acrylic ground and dry components store longer; use as opacifier in gouache)
rabbit skin glue/hide glue (used for grounds, sizing; distemper medium; glue for attaching canvas to board)
metal point (small piece lasts very long; brass can be found for free, or buy/find wire that lasts many life times over; some can fit into a clutch pencil; can coat scrap wood with chalk and or some other ground of your choice in weak glue size and reuse board for scrap drawings, by recoating or scraping)
charcoal powder (can be made for free; decent for ink with suitable binder ground finely; good for paint; use for tracing; many other uses)
egg (yolk and pigment for egg tempera, good for lean underpainting for oil paint or as a cheap and durable paint, don't need entire yolk; can make water-miscible paint by adding to oil paint, thin and clean with water instead of solvents; glair, made by whipping egg white and letting liquid separate from foam, can be used as paint or ink binder; adjust strength with distilled water; can be dried by pouring in a shallow container and letting sit, dissolve again by water; supposedly aged wet, not too tightly sealed glair is better; can be modified by adding honey or sugar etc; used in some varnish recipes; can be use in metal point grounds)

posts.name: Anonymous

>>6372834
None if you use inks, if not then the film isn't strong enough to adhere to the other layers, should be fine if you're just staining the paper. Use gesso, it will create blooms like watercolor.

Too much water will upset the balance and spread the acrylic polymer too thinly so the molecules can't reconnect properly to form a stable film. Instead you should dilute with an acrylic medium, which is essentially the same as the paint but without the color pigment.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6375078
if lead is only a trace element in zinc, imagine how little is in titanium wtth 2-5% zinc. painting with cadmium colors is so much more dangerous at that point.
there's a number of inert pigments that are mostly transparent in the average layer of oil paint you can add to make any pigment more transparent.
calcium carbonate (chalk, egg shells, marble, limestone), silica (crushed glass, pumice, silica-rich sand, quartz). calcium carbonate is safer because silica can damage lungs much more. make a paint mixing the transparent pigment with oil to a consistency you like and add it to your tube paint, or add chalk directly and add oil if it is too lean.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6375089
>By the way, just HOW dangerous is Lead white if you don't grind it yourself? For example are you in trouble if you get it on your skin while painting?
Not in quantities you'd use if it happens a couple of times, but over time you could get yourself in trouble. Lead doesn't really leave your body basically ever once it gets in. By itself, anyway: you can get rid of most of it with Dimercaprol.

If you get it in your food somehow, either by having it in your fingers (Even if it's so little as to not show clearly) or clothes or whatever, that's actually bad. That's why it's recommended to use gloves (Nitrile only: Latex can get dissolved by oil/solvents) and to never eat/drink while in the studio if working with lead white.

Mostly it's a case of "better safe than sorry", but there's genuine long-term health risks that many underestimate.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Whats the difference between using linseed oil vs paint thinner for thinning oil paints?
Everything I can find online seems to talk about them interchangeably, is there a reason to use one over the other?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6390809
+linseed oil makes the paint have more oil (oil to pigment ratio increases) slower drying, more gloss, not as easy to paint over dry, harder for atmospheric vapors and moisture to penetrate, more yellowing, more flexible, used for glazes
+paint thinner makes makes the oil thinner (oil to pigment ratio remains the same but effectively lower since it also breaks down oil) leaner and thinner paint layer, more matte surface, pigment can be unbound if thinned too much, more susceptible to dirt and moisture penetration due to microscopic pores, faster drying, mostly used for under layers

>>6394737
it's not an alternative to thinners. it's more of an alternative to fluid and gel mediums like sunthickened linseed oil or maroger medium. while thinners lower the oil content, fluid and gel mediums increase the oil content.
one should not use too much thinner because pigments lose binder.
one should not use too much fluid/gel medium because the pigments have too much binder and can cause problems like wrinkling or yellowing depending on the medium.

Also try to use brush and ink, the only problem is they can't really use waterproof ink, otherwise it's pretty flexible.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6399981
Brushes and brush pens can be a bit difficult to get used to since you feel much less contact with the surface, but they're a lot of fun. Definitely the most versatile mark-making wise, but it takes a bit of practice to be able to do very fine detail work with them.
Pic related is great since you can control how much ink is loaded on it for drybrush effects and stuff, unlike the Pentel Pocket Brush which is always wet (which makes it a bit more difficult to handle, too).
Dip pens aren't bad choices either, but they also take some getting used to. Just wanted to mention brushes since I feel like they're a bit overlooked these days which is a shame.
Waterproof ink gives brushes a shorter lifespan, but it's not that big of a deal. Pen nibs break and brushes eventually lose their point, but you'll still probably go through them much slower than fineliners.

posts.com:
>>6404987
to clarify
i wasn't talking about watercolor. i meant that even for drawings in dry media i only use pure cotton paper, (but not watercolor cotton paper.) if you explain to buyers of watercolor that something is made of cotton, that's simply expected, especially if the buyer has been in the market for buying watercolor works.
i go beyond what is expected when it comes to materials. for oil painting, the standard is simply to use tube paints, with titanium as the white, over acrylic gesso. i grind from dry pigments, use the best lead white available, and use lead oil ground with the same lead white.
it's not merely an issue of the work fading or deteriorating in 10 years or in their lifetime either. as there are practices and materials that i admit are more archival, but are simply not as beautiful, prestigious, or expensive. aluminum panels, mdf, and plywood are very stable, but are not as inspiring as a joined solid wood panel with hand cut butterfly keys. when it comes to works of art, i consider the support as part of the art, so they must be beautiful as well.
or some materials might outlast others in a few hundred years, but the more available materials are good enough.

posts.com:
>>6415758
there are illustrations of both in use or separately.
palette is good for mixing various tones and making the range of movement more efficient in painting. it also means the paint is somewhat more paste-like. mixtures from the paste can be thinned down with water or more medium, or painted dry thinly. i notice that palettes were generally smaller, because the mixes were simpler and they painted differently colored parts separately, and that the familiar kidney shaped palette became more common later.
shells and bowls are good for fluid paints. the ribs of the shells or the rim of the bowl makes it easy to remove excess moisture from the brush. the bowl shape also means that moisture evaporates slower. one can make different mixes in separate shells but this can be wasteful since you often only need a small amount of each especially since tempera is painted very thinly.

>>6413837
So Copic itself is a brand. I'm not sure if it's the OG alcohol based brush marker, but it's basically the standard. I would have recommended Prismacolor last year if you didn't want to splurge on Copics, but I think they're discontinuing the line since I've been seeing them on major clearance at every art store. With that being said, you could easily get a good deal. I personally prefer Copics over all of the alternate brands (Ohuhu is my least favorite and I think they give Instagram/YouTube artists free sets for the good reviews because they kinda suck in person). If you want new, you can buy them for cheapest on Blick. After Christmas, you'll see a lot of sets for sale on sites like Mercari and that's where I got mine for a really good deal. I like that Copics are refillable, and they get a lot cheaper to use when you're refilling them. Other good Copic alternate brands I like are Kuretake and Tombow (make sure not to accidentally get their water markers). Hope this helps.

>>6366575
>spend more than 10 minutes
All my drawing attempts are agonzingly slow as I spend ages deliberating every single line. I can't imagine getting something done in only ten minutes.
>pick an easier subject
I genuinely don't understand what supposedly makes a subject easier or harder to draw. Everything past basic geometric shapes/forms seems impossibly difficult. I've seen people claim that rocks and trees are easy, which seems crazy to me given that they have such incredibly complex shapes and textures.
>copy literal lines and squares that you drew
I can copy drawings without much issue. The difficulty of drawing for me isn't in measuring or line placement, but in figuring out how the subject could be depicted as a drawing in the first place. I don't have an intuitive understanding of what I'm supposed to be marking with lines, or a clear idea of what process people actually use to draw things. I can also never mentally picture what a drawing of any particular subject would look like. As such, there's very little actually guiding my efforts, which is presumably why I always end up with bizarre indecipherable scribbles.

posts.com:
>>6367712
I had similar problem, but I generally solve it in the canvas, and I let fuck ups ignite more ideas, if I can't picture it, time to look at refs and do some iterations. A good exercise is picking an object like a banana, observe it for a minute, notice the contours, textures, distinctive shapes, now get rid of the banana and draw it as you recall, take your time. Now a copy of it now, check the differences between the 2 drawings.

Some cheap workaround for coming up with something is creating a square in an isometric angle, and just put stuff some simple subjects in it, or you can do it with wonky perspective, but keep a basic angle of view, use your room as reference if you want. Like looking at your desk and pretend that's a little village you're looking at. If you're autistic you can make dioramas too. Also try sculpting, even plastiline is good enough, it's just to start to get you thinking spatially, you need to develop that awareness to think above just abstract lines into a white void, if you need an extra push rely on reference for ideas and details.
Even for awareness you need awareness, it's not just about aping things, but being present, if you have different perspectives you've got yourself better odds at solving problems in your art process.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The only "masteries" are

>line quality

>Perspective

>Anatomy

>Values


Line quality is the best to learn first, deciding what's thick and what's thin, using lines to imply the shape instead of perfectly tracing it out. Anatomy is next, its just measurements. The head is as complex as the entire body, but the key is consistency. Perspective is being able to rotate what you drew and draw it in another angle, usually a more interesting one. Values are colors and shading.

There are things like composition which I would call a mastery but its something you can learn the entire time.

posts.name: Anonymous

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6415532
That article is referring to sight size and I agree it will cripple you in the long run. What you are talking about though is just measuring / comparative measuring, which is just very useful and makes it easier to double check yourself and be more precise. Make sure to have your arm fully stretched while doing it, Proko has a decent vid on it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Holding out your pencil/drawing tool and your thumb to check proportions and compare angles on your subject with the angles you're drawing at various times while you work is not the same as working entirely in the sight-size method, which from a quick glance seems to be what the article is criticizing

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Another anon mentioned it but sighting is holding the pencil and measuring proportions. Sight sizing is what the article is talking about and it involves lightning up the model and the canvas in perspective.

Sighting is good to do especially for checking proportions and does not limit your ability to scale and size. Sightsizing that the article talks about limits this ability which is why it’s not recommended.

If you are a /beg/inner or /int/ermediate in art, please use this thread to post pieces for critique or ask for advice.
Use this thread instead of making new threads or post in the drawthread with fundamental exercises.

RESIZE YOUR IMAGES TO ~1000 PIXELS wide using one of the following methods:
1. screenshot the image and post that instead
2. change camera capture settings to something smaller
3. send to computer and resize in MSPaint

READ THE STICKY:
Completed: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1uwaXKU7ev6Tw_or__o8ARpUb6r2rCZYJGqwSFV9AD98/edit
New collaborative sticky (anyone can edit): https://hackmd.io/UMnZVhNITW-T2wZpHw6d0Q
Old: http://www.squidoo.com/how-to-draw-learn

RECOMMENDED BOOKS FOR BEGINNERS:
Read the sticky

TRY TO BE ACTIVE AND GIVE PEOPLE SOME FEEDBACK.
When giving feedback, avoid vague "advice" - point what's wrong and try to give the anon you're quoting a clear direction to improve their art (study heads < watch THIS VIDEO about head structure, read THIS SECTION of THIS ARTIST'S BOOK, etc).
You, feedback seeking anon, should also try to be clear and concise when asking for critique/help. When posting your artwork, say what you want help with, and what's your goal with the study/artwork.

Keep drawing and you will eventually internalize basic proportions. Some artists rely heavily on construction (e.g. Loomis), others just go for it and count on their skill to lead them to the right place (e.g. Kim Jung Gi). Drawing from imagination is a skill you need to learn like anything else, and even then you aren't really drawing from imagination you are drawing from what you know and have seen.

>>6414429
Dude, you're pressing your pencil way too hard. Get a softer pencil for darker lines.

>>6414621
You're chicken scratching while inking, it IS going to look bad. Next time focus on getting clean and continuous lines. Even if you're not happy with your sketch it will be an opportunity to practice cleaning up a drawing.

>>6414829
There's a lot of symbol drawing going on here. When figure drawing you should focus on what you're seeing instead of what you think something should look like. I find that when starting on figure drawing it can be very confusing to work on a line drawing and shading at the same time. Next time do one of these things:
a. Lines only: Try to observe and translate forms with only lines, using a little bit of hatching to imply contours.
b. Shading only: Using a marker, charcoal, or the side of your pencil you'll observe your reference and try to translate its shapes and volumes using light and shadow only. Focus mostly on big shapes and don't give much attention to small details.

When you feel a little more confident doing these things separately you'll get better results doing both at the same time.

You can try using random references, objects, or associations you have with words and incorporate that in a design in any way you can.

Make bee armor. Carrot weapons. Stalactite gloves. Whatever. It'll suck, but you'll actively think about why it sucks and subconsciously create preferences. At some point you'll find things in your designs that you like, and then it's just a matter of isolating that.

Every object has a colour scheme, textures, other qualities, etc. You need to be conscious of that if you want to design cool shit.

make her head longer and give her a fucking chin. git rid of that miku faggot anime style chin now. it will always make you art look beg.

the right has thumb placement is off, the connection should be visible, or slightly visible, which means you'd see 2 or 3 of the thumb joints. the left elbow is too high and upper arm is too short. git rid of the unessesary lines near the hips, it adds nothing and hurts my eyes.

the left hand is terrible. but you knew that.

the right lower leg thats bent should be visible and not just dissappear. same with the left leg.

the tit gap at the top shouldnt ge that big.. just draw a small indent, or shorten those lines.

Overall: Work on head contruction (NOW), Get better at emotions/expressions, practice hads till you get em right, make sure the elbow lines up COMFTORBALLY with the hip bone, like right on top of it, get rid of unessecary lines on the bdoy (especially when drawing females), work on your legs (david finch has great vids on legs), and get better at rendering.

very long critique but valid.

also pic rel is what i'd say do for the left hand.

>>6412618
Odds are its a problem with your learning process or art making process. There is not much to say. You have to always review your process and correct it. Just make sure you have properly set long and short term goals, with deadlines if possible. They will prevent you from being led astray when grinding fundies or studies.

Also, avoid being guided by "feeling", try to be accurate whether you are doing studies or drawing from imagination instead of guessing things (measure things, check for angles, construct a perspective frame etc). Guessing is a thing we see the pros doing often, but they can only do it because they trained their intuition. If you are a beginner you probably have poor intuition.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6412715
There's not a level you "should" be at, everyone learns differently. Using your time to study wisely instead of drawing aimlessly will definitely make you improve faster, and I say that as someone who didn't use their time wisely.
>Spend only half of your time practicing fundamentals
For an absolute beginner Keys to Drawing is a must. For a beginner Drawabox and Dynamic Bible covers penmanship and perspective and using construction quite well. The rest of your time you should be drawing what YOU want. Make complete pieces, they won't look great, but they will show you want you need to practice.
>Focused specific practice is very powerful.
You notice that your hands don't come out how they should? Focusing on drawing hands. Hands from every angle, challenge yourself. At the end try drawing whatever it was from memory.
>Look at artwork
Don't just look, you have to get into the artist's mind. Why did they choose that colour? Why that shape there? Look at how they do the thing you're studying, how are they simplifying hands?
>1/2

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6412962
>2/2
>Be self critical
This is probably one of the most, if not the most important things if you don't have a teacher or mentor. Sure you can post online but you have a good chance of getting crabbed or receiving bad advice. Be careful of what advice you take, including mine. Always look for things you can improve. Setting good goals is very important as well.
Using myself as an example now, My goal now is to draw clean line art so I do studies like >>6408217 where I focus on using simple lines. Then I will do a "complete" piece like picrel (I will render it later). What did I learn from this piece then that I can use for next time?
>the feet
I didn't figure out how the feet will sit in space in the sketch so now it looks wrong. Next time I will spend more time on the sketch
>line weight
it's all over the place, I'll try to improve it later, but I need to look at how other artists approach this
>the shoes
I really need to study some shoes, but I won't and it leads to the next point
>It has to be fun
You need to enjoy yourself, disregard anything that is not fun to you.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6412909
Just extend lines from background elements that can be used for comparison with your character. In your example, you might want to draw beyond the borders of the picture because your character is in the foreground. You could extend the perspective lines of the door to where the character is standing and then project some horizontals to show you the height of the door at that location (since the character has to be a little shorter than the doorway).
>That's not intuitive!
It is if you know perspective. You don't even have to use a ruler. Just know the rules and rough it in.

>>6398124
Apprentices back in the day primarily copied older works. Michelangelo was apprenticed late (at 13) to Domenico Ghirlandaio, and left one year later having nothing more to learn. Largest amount of his practice was self-propelled, though as he was under the wing of Lorenzo de´ Medici, he had access to the Medici art collection to study from - primarily ancient roman statues.
These days you have access to way more art, and the method to learn from it remains the same: Copy it until you can produce your own. Download art, get a good quality print made, and copy it. Rinse and repeat. Go to a museum to sketch, rinse and repeat. That really is almost all there is to it. The rest is knowing your materials, on which there's tons of resources of incredible quality available now.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6400294
>to add, apprentices were accepted based on if they showed skill, so many must have been quite good already before entering.
Not necessarily true. Many were entered at an age young enough that they wouldn't've shown much skill at all. Andrea del Sarto was apprenticed at 7 years of age. He was a son of a tailor, and was apprenticed to a goldsmith because he liked to draw. It was more of a "looks like my son doesn't enjoy this thing that I do for a living, and enjoys artistic stuff, and I have enough sons that one of them will inherit the family business." kind of thing.
This was a financial agreement first and foremost: Parents still paid the master for their kids upkeep, but the master had to pay wages to their apprentices. And yes, this means that most apprentices were earning money from apprenticing from about 10 years of age.

>and the studio training included hands on projects and learning how to prepare things
Yes. Especially grinding pigments and preparing panels. Then learning to draw, by copying other artists or their masters. Then drawing from statuettes and casts, then from statues, then from live models. Then painting - usually the less important parts of their masters' paintings.

>they also learned how to design different objects and decorations in the meantime
You weren't usually allowed to design anything until your apprenticeship period was over, unless your master was *really* busy, like Neri di Bicci. You would've *worked* on those decorations though, applying your master's designs.

>there can't have been that much time spent for instructing into figure drawing in the same way that modern courses do.
There was quite a lot, usually apprentices drawing each other in various poses, etc. This served a dual purpose: To train them, and to create a library of drawings that could be used for parts of more finished work later. These collections were extremely valuable at the time, and often the most important item in a master's will.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6406910
7 is quite young for apprenticeship or learning how to draw. around the teenage years is more common, with some even being late teens. the first steps into getting into painting before a proper apprenticeship was often drawing from public frescoes and sculptures, and other artists were often present drawing as well, or had informal training under artist relatives outside of the guild system.
i think the tiered system of progression from casts to real sculptures and so on is an idea partly from later training method, simply due to sculptures being available for the public to see, and there's no reason why an apprentice would have to draw from a cast first if the studio has their own sculptures.
i didn't say that they worked on the decorations themselves for the master to use during their apprenticeship, but that it's something they learned. especially if they apprenticed under a goldsmith or carver in wood or stone which many of them did, or trained under someone with such a background. even if apprenticed under a painter, among the drawings they had access to copy would be supplemental designs.
i just mean this training is unlike modern courses that focus mostly on teaching how to draw figures, in that it is more encompassing and also more hands-on with the production process. it's also why so many came out as architects as well. in rare cases like taddeo zucchero's he was not even allowed to draw unless it was in his own time.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6408609
>7 is quite young for apprenticeship or learning how to draw. around the teenage years is more common, with some even being late teens
10 was average. Michelangelo is historically notable for apprenticing as late as 13, as he received formal education in other subjects due to being of minor nobility class.

>i think the tiered system of progression from casts to real sculptures and so on is an idea partly from later training method, simply due to sculptures being available for the public to see, and there's no reason why an apprentice would have to draw from a cast first if the studio has their own sculptures.
This was renaissance. They wanted to draw from *old roman sculptures*, which were not so readily available then. It was an aesthetic choice on what to emulate first and foremost. Relatively few studios would've kept finished statues around anyhow: they take up a lot of space, and real estate market in Florence or Venice wasn't cheap even at the time.

>it is more encompassing and also more hands-on with the production process
Oh yeah, absolutely. "Artists", in the modern sense, weren't really a category back then - they were classified as artisans, worked in similar quarters and earned similar wages.

>in rare cases like taddeo zucchero's he was not even allowed to draw unless it was in his own time.
Zuccaro worked as an assistant to Daniele da Parma, not an apprentice - a quite an important distinction.

they had no problem drawing from contemporary sculptures or those from previous generation even if roman sculpture was considered superior, just as the students copied frescoes and sometimes publicly displayed cartoons. if the studio had sculptures or ancient fragments, or there are sculptures in the city there is no reason to withhold drawing from sculptures until one has done casts. if few studios had sculptures then the progression of cast to sculpture is not part of a structured curriculum as is often repeated. even early on in the renaissance before classicism was a main force in the renaissance, drawing from classical sculpture was already practiced.
you are right that there is a distinction, though i meant an earlier painter he was employed as an assistant under, called giovanni piero calabrese. this likely means he was a journeyman who has finished apprenticeship and could work as a day laborer for other studios by that time. although it shows how much time can be spent grinding colors and other errands for a master.

It does... kind of. When you're a pro with a tight deadline like a WSJ manga, you can hire assistants to help with the gruntwork. However, having done this myself, it's not that simple. You can't "just" hand over an unfinished page and get it back perfect, it requires detailed explanations of what you want, usually style guide/references and then when you inevitably get back drawings that didn't look how you wanted at all you need to explain exactly what's wrong with it and exactly how you want it fixed (and likely still not get back what you wanted in the first place) and a lot of the time end up just drawing it correctly yourself anyway. Maybe japanese assistants are just better than who I've worked with, but there's still no real way around all the schedule management and communication issues working with assistants create. So ultimately it's not like it's taking a drawing that would take you 4 hours to draw and turning it into 0 hours of your time, you're still going to end up spending significant time and energy preparing the work and then reviewing the work the assistant turns in.
Plus there's the factor that it totally breaks your flow if you're used to working on your own, but idk if that's an issue for authors who are used to working with assistants.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6406802
>most people when they want that they consume animation, or video games, not comics,
They consume that stuff as well. You're just talking about preference for medium, not the qualities of the medium itself.
>Anon, Bleach, and specially Dragon Ball Z/Super are 99.9% art, and 00.01% "story"
Dragonball's another fantastic example of using the medium to tell the story. It's a very compelling read, despite the story being very one-note, and that's because the author knew how to use art and story in tandem.
I'm saying the art is PART of the "story", or rather, it's the medium for telling it. You'd understand this if you ever made comics, or movies, or really any storytelling medium that blends other mediums to tell a story. It's not as simple as throwing some text or audio on an image, there's much more to it than that. Choosing what image, how you draw it, how you phrase the text, if you use text at all or a lot of it etc are all STORYTELLING choices that are not STORY choices. Do you understand? It's a fundamental part of making comics to tell a story with visuals, and it takes skill to do so.
To use another medium as an example to help clarify: moviemakers are not necessarily photographers, because shooting a movie uses multiple mediums to tell a story, while a photographer's primary (and perhaps only) goal is capture a single moment or a series of single moments, to show off a bunch of pretty pictures. They are fundamentally different, and a movie can succeed at telling a story with visuals and sound and movement while not having very many pretty pictures at all, or not having very good writing or whatever.

>>6402639
That's a very hard artstyle, Anon. You're using a lot of shading and relatively realistic depictions.anga benefits from a more simplified and cartoony style but even then the shading can be a killer. The whole reason Goku went super Saiyan in the first place was because it was taking the artist too much time to shade his hair so he had to come up with a reason to be able to just draw an outline of it in a more simplified pattern.

For a western example. My partner can recreate an entire storyboard of Adventure Time in less than 30 minutes, but that's because it's a very simplified cartoon style. Of you're going to do something that in depth you'll want to probably find a way to do it digital and copy/paste of do like an old school animation thing and have reusable background you can layer figures over on a see through sheet. Otherwise you'll need a couple of assistants to split the pages with and work 12-16 hour shifts to make that kind of schedule

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6411119
Animation memes are interesting because the majority of videos aren't any deeper than 'here's my oc's backstory'. AMs are designed to be repetitive and look alike. You can draw with different artstyles, and use different colors and music, but the vast majority are just headbops. Children like them because they are repetitive.
Because AMs became so popular, in ~2017, the community collapsed under the weight of copycats and art drama. I haven't looked at the community on Youtube for a while, so I don't know how popular the videos are. On Scratch, a kid-focused website (I've used it since I was a kid and I still like it), children and teens still make them. It's easy for a child to draw/animate a headbop instead of, for example, a dance.
Even though animation memes aren't deep, young people still like them. Unless you have complicated backgrounds or movements, AMs are easy to make. They're a stepping stone to more complex animation, and that's all they should be treated as.

>>6408532
Artists study more than one influence. Steve Rude doesn't just copy Toth, there's Steranko, Kirby, Frazetta and stuff. Art is rarely made in a vacuum, and when it is your lack of input starts limiting you really fast.
When it comes to appeal there's really no getting out of studying other people. It's not that you're meant to copy their choices verbatim and become a dollar store version of the original, but use your studies to understand why they do things the way they do and use that to inform your decisions.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6408339
Appeal is subject to things like pop culture and trendsetters. All you can do is either chase mass appeal and copy the most current popular art, or chase your inner desires and appeal to yourself first and foremost. One will bring you riches, the other will bring you internal fulfillment. Sometimes what you personally like will overlap with what is popular, and that's kind of an ideal scenario.
Art online is like giving a stranger a free gift in the middle of a department store where everything is free. It better be a kickass gift if you expect them to care.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6414267
A lot of commonly repeated facts you hear are outdated, wrong, or half-truths. People also use terms incorrectly all the time. Color comes from physical properties and how your brain perceives it too, so it gets quite complicated.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4enFjTGVTnc
http://www.huevaluechroma.com/index.php
This guys videos and website are quite good, you should check them out.

For simplifications you can actually apply to painting, these are decent.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=p0rVUhXnmpY
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gJ2HOj22gDo
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4LhcNbFMkTw
https://twitter.com/devinkorwin/status/1278049901709012995

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6414294
Awesome thanks

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
There are two mistakes people usually make when talking about color theory:
1) Thinking that our perception of color is equal across the spectrum when its actually heavily skewed towards red; there's a reason why there are cultures in which they even thought green and blue were the same color and most people still don't recognize cyan as a separate color from blue.
2) Ignoring context as if blindly following a color wheel will automatically make your work good; in nature color contrast plays both attractive and repelling roles; think a ripe fruit vs a poisonous animal.

Original drawer here (Refer to the Drywall with a Falcon 2), ready to give some clarification:
In this universe, Drywall and Molly are in a committed relationship; Scud and Mr. Bumpy have made a pact with one another in order to break up this relationship and get their best friends back.
In this drawing, Scud is ranting about how Molly’s smile (more specifically, her wide, toothy grin that she makes in some episodes of BitN such as S1E8 Party Poopers) is creepy to him. I wanted to extend the storyline by having Scud mock Molly by grabbing a marker from Drywall and drawing a smile on his face (“YOU SEE THIS?! DO YOU SEE THIS SHIT?!?! THIS IS HOW A SMILE IS SUPPOSED TO LOOK: CLEAN AND FUCKING SIMPLE!!! NOT FUCKING EMBROIDERED!!!!!”) but it was late and I had a final exam to do in, literally, a few hours.

Hope that explains everything. :^)


P.S. Drywall’s dialogue can be translated as: “Scud!!! Stop being mean to Molly you FUCKING PRICK!”

What is /ALT/?
If you're looking for a place to post your cartooning then you've found the right general. This is /ic/s 1st and only merged hub where both Eastern and Western stylization can coexist peacefully, hence the double title.
>Rules & Guidelines
(1) Any form of cartooning is welcome; so submit and receive feedback from others. (2) Please resize your images before posting. (3) Share your knowledge and (4) Remember to not be afraid of asking for critique. Most importantly, keep discussion at a civil level
>I came for anime. Why does the image OP say cartoons general?
To distinguish from the anime study thread (janitor supported). Please post your studies there and personal work goes here.
------
>Community Resources
>Tag the OP if you want a resource included here.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6345321
I think it's a matter of inspiration and habits. I'm a big fan of Deathburger, Geof Darrow and Moebius. I replicated a lot of things by studying these, including saturating the canvas with detail. I guess it became an automatism after doing it for years. WHAT to (specifically) draw in areas is often context dependant, but also composition dependant. There are time where you don't want to fill certain area to create some sort of rythm in the visuals.

>>6345321
This is >>6344835. I think part of it is influences (I'm also fan of Geof Darrow and Moebius and also Arthur Adams). Part of it is understanding my limitations (I don't like how my crosshatching turns out so I prefer to use details to communicate values rather than hatching). Final part is readability, but this is more of a gut thing for me. Sometimes I just feel a part of the piece is missing something (in my "bluff" pic, the troll looked too blank without the skin blemishes). Hope this helps.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6346855
>I will consciously try to make over-detailed drawings for a while, as an experiment
Go for it! I think this is a great time to take risks. Couple things to keep in mind as you experiment. Details draw the eye, so if you aren't careful they could distract from the main subject of the piece (but they can also guide the eye to the subject). Work in stages, each stage adding more details. Also, details are a good way (esp. in ink) to turn mistakes into "happy accidents"

>>6346855
im sorry i misunderstood. to give an idea how i personally go about it, my fairy one would be good to talk about since that was put together mostly piecemeal:
>pencil in fairy giving candy. lollipops are typical candy imagery, so go with that
>want my three characters to be expressive. young boy is kind of pushy, so hes up front. tall boy is older, so more apprehensive
> want to fill in the foreground, so decided to do children also eating candy. gives the idea of a "living" world. also kids are fun to draw
> think it would be funny to have the tooth fairy in cahoots with the dentist, so decide to insinuate a dentist building in the background. also funny to me to have an ominous dentist shadow just standing there menacingly
> make loopy letters to go along with lollipop swirls. add lights to five it a "carnival" vibe
> start inking foreground and midground. i want the fairy character to be slightly ominous, but not "evil" so keep hatch shading to a reasonable amount
> chose to go with bricks for the building, as its common facade work for buildings like that. think of adding ivy for foliage and interest, but decide against it as it would look too cluttered
> brick inking is a typical style ive done before, just using a tried and true, low-effort brick shading
> decide to add a little screaming boy in the far right window to fill it in and it makes me smile
so, as dumb as it sounds, im kind of making up a "story" as i go, and that helps me piece it together. another popular artist who does this is bob ross, just watch some of his vids and he makes up a "story" for it as he goes. also, weirdly enough, meatcanyon is also good to watch as he has a similar wandering train of thought as he does his sketches.

>light smudges into the black is great, howd you do that?
I was making it up as I went along. First I toned the paper with colored inks (teal, blue, magenta), then I added the black, then I used a cotton ball with white ink and "dry brushed" the bokeh effect using a circle template as a mask.

>>6349056
Day 28. Leaned a new thing. If you use the liquid latex type resists when doing alcohol ink washes after inking do not put the ink washes down heavily. It can cause the resist itself to seep into the top layer of your paper (I was using Bristol rather than watercolor paper). If this happens when you try to remove the resist it will remove the top layer of paper and take any line work with it. That's what happened to the moon in the upper left. It seems to be fine if you just do light alcohol washes and let them dry between though. Watercolor paper may be a little more resilient.

posts.com:
>>6354175
Wash looks good. I too struggle with streaky washes when using alcohol, but you can mitigate that by using a little water or just doing water + ink washes. The streakyness is because the alcohol is evaporating really fast. It's a double edged sword. On one hand it keeps the paper from buckling, on the other if you're not fast enough you'll get streaks in large areas. It's great for building up localized shadow quickly without over wetting the paper though.

I've done that on a couple and it's worked out well. I'm not using the best paper for it right now, so I still get some buckling even if I tape it down. Still, may be worth doing wet-on-wet with water for large areas and then come in with alcohol to build the localized shadow, etc.

You won't have any issues learning anatomy, but there's a lot to learn and a lot of rote memorization to have to grind through so it's a monumental task nonetheless. Learning to be able to draw an anatomically accurate skeleton from memory is a Herculean task of its own.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6413473
Foreshortening is hard, especially the extreme kind with lens warp. And even more difficult is mastering the human head at all angles. Facial features are so diverse and there's a hundred tiny forms in all that detail and everyone has different measurements and proportions. We recognize even the smallest uncanny mistakes in faces, especially faces we recognize, and drawing the same exact face well, without referencing, from all angles, takes mastery of perspective and form and anatomy.

posts.sub: Why most artists do not know this?
posts.com:
>TL:DR - AI-Generated graphics are always public domain. Therefore, not copyrightable.
>Yes, this matters a lot.

So, basically if you don't want to be replaced by weird, autistic and nihilistic coding bros, I suggest you do not allow them to manipulate law-makers and the public at large saying otherwise.

>Why are you posting this? This thread is for artwork discussion only.

Well, yeah but this matters a lot for artists. Please don't make me regret posting this here.

>Besides, /his/ only wants to talk about obscure shit nobody cares about. Most of the time.

>Anon, this sounds great! But I know nothing about copyright laws, plus I think you're dumb and this is fake.

As for the law, it basically boils down to this: if you lie about copyright laws (in this case, saying such graphics can be copyrighted) you are committing copyfraud since everything AI spits out is public domain, no exceptions.
Code cannot sign contracts, cannot give away property, cannot have SSN, etc.

>Why are you doing this, then?

Because I see almost no artist out there pointing out this simple, valid legal fact.

>What can I do to make this more widespread on society?

Just go out there and talk to people about it.

This is your fate. This is what you chose. There is no turning back.

>>6414074
>>What's the highest aspiration of a codemonkey?
The term "codemonkey" is often used as a pejorative term to refer to a programmer or software developer, and it suggests that they are just a mindless worker who simply follows orders and writes code without any thought or creativity. As such, it is difficult to say what the highest aspiration of a "codemonkey" might be, as it depends on the individual and their personal goals and motivations. Some programmers may be motivated by a desire to solve complex technical problems and create innovative software, while others may be more focused on career advancement or financial gain. Ultimately, the aspirations of any individual, regardless of their profession, are likely to be unique and personal to them.

NTA but
>detail

That's not what the difference between the two is, or at least not the true difference. You're only seeing the surface level. The real differences here are

1.) A far better understanding of form. The face on the right is the most striking example, the way that the eyes are drawn indicates the head as a rounded volume with mass, whereas the left is a flat shape with sticker eyes applied to it. The jacket, clothes and even hair made of distinct, solid masses overlaid upon and wrapping around the body in layers. They all feel like they have weight and force applied to them as well. If you were really paying attention, you'll also notice very subtle indicators implying forms like the bones and tendons of the hand and the wrist under the skin- like the clothes, there is a feeling of the skin stretched upon and wrapping around these delicate forms.

2.) Better understanding of subject matter. Not only does the artist have a better understanding of human anatomy, they have an understanding of the anatomy of EVERYTHING in the piece. The jacket, the shirt, the pants, the hair, the skin and bone, they know the parts, the materials, how they fit together, and most importantly WHY that they are the way they are and act the way they do. This is why the clothes, the hair, the skin have such definite mass and purposeful application of forces upon them. See those crisp, chunky folds in the jacket on the right and compare them to the almost vacuum sealed, skintight jacket on the left with muddy indefinite marks indicating the idea of wrinkles that the artist knows should be there but doesn't understand how they work as 3D form, or the properties of the material that they're deforming.

I'll try to list what the details are hopefully so me and others can know what to look for.

The pose is the same between them, lets say the reference picture was just like the pose on the left.

Drawing exactly what you see in the reference is good practice, but you can take the time to "improve" every step of the process, and go beyond the reference. I think that's what he did here, because ist not like you will find a picture you can copy 100% and leave it as it is.

>Jacket
The old jacket is quite normal, the wrinkles are all over the place which might be realistic but you can add character into everything you draw, including wrinkles. The right pic changes the type of coat completely, its now more of a rain coat made of a heavier material. The sleeves are way wider, and it looks too big for her, that creates appeal.

>jeans
The left pic has very basic wrinkles added as a halfasssed attempt, just being more careful with sticking to proper anatomy makes a huge difference in tight clothes. The pic on the right has her legs closer to the correct length, and it wrinkles only where it bends. Which is mostly better to do.The waist of her jeans also dip down as it can in real life, instead of being perfectly horizontal as I would have drawn it. It has a 3d form as it goes aroudn her waist, and you can see it with the belt loops, so it goes in a circle AND it dips down, creating a whole lot of depth. In the left pic, its all obscured by the long sweater which is not drawn to be round at all if you look at the hem.

>body
the head is tilted on two axis, down and away, she's not facing the camera, which adds appeal. Her hair slumps down and travels along her body like water, adding more depth. Left girl has everything drawn separately as if it was pasted on, right girl has every element interacting with each other with gravity.

running out of characters but the sweater crop adding shadow is another depth thing

posts.name: Anonymous

>>6408616
That's true. However, the right eye's (our left) perspective is a little off. It doesn't match the shape of the other eye, or conform to the eye socket and surface of the face correctly.
Errors aside, even at a more frontal angle the eyes can still be pushed to feel more three dimensional. If you look at her other artworks where she's drawing normally, you'll notice that she always pushes the eyes as close to the side of the face as she can to create a feeling of them curving around the form of the head, even in straight frontal shots. It's not something exclusive to her either, if you pay attention, you'll actually see this technique being used in a lot of anime and anime-style artwork. It's a more subdued form of forced perspective that, while not technically correct, sells a heightened feeling of depth to the viewer.
Incidentally, this is why 3D modeling and animating in the anime style is so difficult.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6404281
Connections are the main thing, but school provides
>structured learning
it tells you what to learn and when. Yes you can find all the resources and books on the internet, but its just way too much for anyone to delve into without guidance. Have a structured form of guidance that tells you what should be learned first and for how long really helps you focus on what's important, rather than say getting trapped up in anatomy for 2 years when you're a /beg/ who can't into a straight line.
>Deadlines and grades
it forces you to get stuff done. The pressure can be good. I have a sub to NMA that just sits there, once a week i'll watch a video or something but i just have no pressure to work on anything in specific so i'll often to regress to doing whatevers comfortable. anime waifus.
>Actual coaching and mentoring
while instructors are hit or miss, if you actively go to them for help most of them are willing to help you out, give you guidance, and give you actual critiques. its not something you can easily get elsewhere and /ic/ is not a valid replacement for an actual rpofessional pointing out your problems and giving you advice.

Its probably not worth 100k or whatever it costs. but considering how much degrees are pushed on people now days, if its what you want to do you could be wasting money in worse ways. And at worst you still get the school connections.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6410353
To an extent, but if you were actually trying (which is the hard part to get people to do) it gives you a good enough foundation that you can start to easily pick things up because now you understand "how to learn", and you have the background foundational skills/knowledge to actually make sense of what you're trying to learn.

There's a huge difference between the
>how do i learn to draw when i can't even draw a stickfigure!
phase and the
>I know how to draw some good portraits and have lots of paintings under my belt, but I don't know how to draw armor
phase. the latter you know what you want to do and what you need to learn. and hopefully after school you know how to actually make sense of what you're looking at when you do armor studies.

but the hard part is getting kids to actually want to learn and not just half ass the assignments and lessons.

Otaku culture has become very inbred. The first successful mangaka were drawing on sources which were not manga. The next generation imitates them, but still brings in some outside influences from film or other media. Then you get to something like, say, Evangelion, which is being made by otaku for otaku; it's a remixing of all tropes already present in the medium—but even then it can do something novel with them and spawn a host of immitators. But that was 20 years ago and now we're in what, a fourth or fifth generation of anime/manga? It's inbred. How many video game fantasy isekai series are there now? Yes there's the advantage that the chinese cartoons aren't required to be about the latest versions of Spiderman, Batman, or Superman to have sales and an audience, but if instead they are all about "loser gets sent into a jrpg to be the player character" what can you really do with that story at this point that would be of any interest to people who aren't culturally inbred? Westerns, kung-fu, fucking Christianity itself, and adapting stories from authors of various backgrounds.

But, if it's only known tropes familiar across all the other anime/manga, it gets old.
short answer: Yes, weebs/otaku need to branch out and enjoy other genres. Not just video games, either. Movies, books, etc., too.

A lot of older anime had a, for lack of a better explanation, surprisingly universal style. There was the fanservice and violence, but that just played more into the idea that it was edgier and less kiddy rather than just being the weird self referential incestuous mess it is now. If you took something like Lodoss and Escaflowne they wouldn't stand out as all that different from a lot of western fantasy, granted by all rights they are, but that's sort of my point. It's creators were taking their inspiration from a broader source than just anime. Even Slayers would just come off as sort of silly, but not alienating, to someone who doesn't know anime. They might not GET all the jokes, but there's nothing that they'd find insurmountable. There was always the big eyes, lack of noses and general japan view point, but the creators weren't just making anime because they liked anime. It's like the isekai problem. The genre was already there, but we didn't really have a specific word for it till fairly recently, otherwise it was just treater as regular fantasy, now that it's a self aware thing it's gotten way more copy pasted with maybe a cheap gimmick to stand out rather than a proper story.

If anything it's an incredibly freeing medium, but along with that comes a higher necessary skill level on the part of the creator to make it shine. I feel you're describing a novel instead; each book has the same format of lines aligned in rows along the page, and although it's possible to describe complicated emotions and intricate physical objects verbally that usually requires a lot of prose, much of which is inevitably useless and flowery
as a comics artist you're juggling a lot more responsibilities, but with that you gain a lot more freedom in how you express your stories. more versatile than pure written word and more efficient than animation

A lot of manga, regardless of how wide in scope it may be in terms of genre and subject and end up having very predictable and shallow characters and interactions. An overwhelming amount of manga ends up being about doing your best and helping your friends. Hirohiko Araki somewhat spells this out in Manga in Theory and Practice when he defines the parameters of what makes a popular manga (there can never be negative stories or setbacks etc.). He goes out of his way to say that Jojo is in fact not a 'weird' manga at all but one which adheres to very precise expectations from readers. Manga isn't as obviously formulaic as say capeshit but it's still constrained by formulas. I think this is what the OP quote is getting at, that readers still have a set of fairly rigid expectations despite the diverse approach to genre you find within manga and this can be creatively stifling.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6407090
The muddiness tends to stem from your initial value painting, not the coloring method. Rather than thinking there is a best method, you should learn what actually happens with each and use them when appropriate.
-Multiply layer will pull all of your color values down towards desaturated black. This requires the most consideration for the color value you initially pick.
-Overlay layer will pull your color value in two directions, both desaturated white and desaturated black. This gives you the most direct control, but requires the most manual work.
-Color layer is similar to overlay. It pulls the color towards a desaturated white, but a saturated black. This requires more careful consideration of the saturation you use.
-Gradient map assigns a specific color along a gradient to each value. This can be fast and produce interesting results, but involves a lot of careful masking work.
All of these methods require varying levels of overpainting and tweaking, and that's probably what you're not doing.

The lightest values should be less saturated (more towards white) than the mid tones. In other words, you're missing the reflective highlights

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
There is no one way to automatically get something that works, every method has a downside along with the upsides.
Gradient maps result in banding/artifacts if you overdo them, but they give fine tune control.
Best blend modes are Multiply (will always darken so you'll have to go back in and paint over, but it's good as a starting point if your intention is to manually color later), and Overlay/Hardlight (Overlay risks blowing out the contrast, particularly with very dark or very light colors, and Hardlight destroys contrast with overly light and dark colors).
"Color" blend mode was designed for coloring b/w photographs, so it works well only if you paint your greyscale with the local color values in mind (if thatst he case working directly with color might be better).
In the end you'll always have to eyeball the result and adjust accordingly, including playing with the opacity of any blend mode layers you use. It'll never be as simple as laying in flats by color picking from a reference sheet.

they’re not exactly paintings but wood engravings.
in the early days of printing you needed to dip a sort of stencil with an image engraved into ink, then stamp that onto paper to reproduce that image. wood engraving were literally that. entire “paintings” were carved into wooden tiles, which could then be used to reproduce those images in various publications. reading the Wikipedia article will tell you more bout it cause I, living in the modern age, only have a vague idea how it works

it’s worth mentioning that you’ll often come across pen and ink drawings emulating famous wood cut artists, as the basic principles of each discipline over lap significantly . for some styles of pen and ink, woodcuts are sort of like an ancestor of sorts.

Is this your work anon? Looking beautiful.

As for selling, i recommend packing the prints on some mounting board in plastic cellophane sleeves and going to local cafes/gift shops. Cafes have worked the best for me, I displayed my work on the walls and put some small prints and cards at the checkout. People would pay for their coffee and impulse buy pretty illustrations from a local artist. Greetings cards sell very well and they would be simple + fast to make by woodblock printing.
Impulse buys and anything under $20 has been selling the best for me.

Jesus, you weren't kidding. There really are 900+ works. You have more dedication that most folks here. Nice job, but I find it hard to believe you've made so many drawings of essentially the same thing, yet you don't get enjoyment from it. Is that really true? I said to give up because you didn't enjoy it. This shouldn't be a chore, it should be fun and rewarding to some degree. You'd be doing yourself a disservice continuing if it's not enjoyable at all. I'm not saying this to be mean or anything. That goes for any hobby/craft.

A learning disability will make it hard, and it explains a lot. You should have mentioned that before. If you really want to improve, then studying anatomy is not the next step, in my opinion. You should learn how to represent 3D space in 2D. That's the most basics of all basics. Several different ways to do this. Drawing from life is one way, others recommend grinding boxes and other simple 3D shapes. This type of practice exposes you to the basics of the fundamentals of drawing. These drawing fundamentals are how artists make good work. That holds true even for abstract artists and ones with heavily stylized work; it all comes from a place of understanding of the fundamentals. These are mental tools that must be practiced until you 'get it'. For some people, this takes a long time, while it clicks for others relatively quickly. I think anatomy is a more advanced topic to tackle a little bit later.

Doing all of that means ditching this 'abstract' stuff for the time being and changing your perspective on drawing. Up to you if you really want to. Good luck, Steven!

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6412595
>Is my art a bit too abstract to make any sense at all?
The scale between so-called "abstract" and precise representation has nothing to do with the value of what you're doing. You make that decision. No one can tell you that something you're doing is too abstract. Although someone probably will, because the board you're on is mainly occupied by people who value conventional ways of constructing images.

Though I will say, I kind of agree with the point earlier anon made about digital abstract not really working. The more minimal your composition is in a painting, the more room you leave for the material aspect of the work to breathe (contrasting different textures, volume of the paint, the canvas underneath and so on). With digital there's no material or location to speak of.

>Should I just give up on this and concentrate all my efforts on studying anatomy instead?
If what you're doing doesn't feel right, then start exploring other ways. Go to museums too, instead of just looking at realistic concept art online. There's so much more out there than ArtStation and 4chan. Whether anatomy and fundies are a good direction to move towards depends what you want to make. It's not as important as one might think on this board, in my opinion.

Commercial friendly skills? Learning to speak to people and learning to sell. Even on a basic level. Ironically I started to draw because I dreaded and hated both but unironically these are two of the most useful skills any artist can have. Besides, it's so much easier on the internet too. Now I'm not saying be a clown and put on a mask and let your "personality" carry you or whatever, practice art, get better but learn to communicate, market and to value yourself and your art properly. If you are unable to make money that way or maybe you do not have the time anymore, invest in a skill that will generate you income that isn't drawing. It sucks but you never fully give it up, you're just taking a break. That's the truth of the bucket, there is a false sense of urgency and competition surrounding you, some of it healthy most of it devastating for you psychologically. You are not on a timer, you have an entire life ahead of you. You want real wisdom? Make some money right now so you can chill in the future. Making money from art isn't easy without compromise. Identify a profitable niche and draw. If you are not ok with compromising and doing something you don't want to, like fetish commissions etc then find a way of making money that is appealing to you immediately and either treat it as a side activity or put some sort of emphasis on it. You will not be young and a neet forever. The longer you put this off the worse it's gonna get. Just a few years ago I was a dead inside brokie eating almost expired canned fish once a week. Don't waste your youth on a dream without a concrete goal and financial stability.
The rest depends on your goals. When I'm not sure which fundamental to practice I try to remember what made me start drawing in the first place and how can I make it better. For me, unironically I just wanted to draw figures as good as Vilppu. Now I have the time to achieve that goal in my own time. Hopefully you will too.

It will never get easier, you just get better. If you really want something, you'll get it.

1. Learn communication, public speaking and sales skills regardless of whatever you're doing in life
2. Spend time and energy researching ways to acquire financial stability and then committing on something you actually enjoy. (dont bother with university or higher education, literal teens are making more money than everyone on this board combined right now)

Your parents or whatever net you have sustaining you is not going to hold forever. You need to be prepared. I'm from the old guard of 2010 with guys like tehmeh, parsakoira and shitposters artofguy. It has been frustrating for me to see the board throughout the years but nevertheless the art spirit is still alive. It lives on with you. You just need to figure out your path more clearly but it will be hard without stability, you run the risk of losing yourself(like me for a while). Each new generation that refuses to conform to what everyone else is doing to go their own path. Not because of arrogance or dunning kruger but because they just want to be better and succeed. That is a true artist.

To give an example, I invested 1200$ in a tech stock that had bullish sentiment a few years back, after a year I have made a total of 200$ overall despite it's price value going up, except that if you zoomed out on the chart you could see that it's being hedged down over and over to a consolodiation every 2nd month to maintain a slow steady pace. For an entire year. Welcome to stocks. If you do not have a lot of money you will not make money. any good video courses about arcs of movement and figure drawing in perspective?
Loomis doesn't teach this in-depth (pic related)
and most perspective books are about buildings and backgrounds, not characters

I want to know how long is the arc supposed to be, I always have a problem with extreme angles, most people just eyeball it, like
>"lol the hand is close to the camera so I'm gonna draw it super big xD"
but fuck that, I want to be precise and I don't want to rely on 3d models all the time
the only good one I found is this one from manga materials;
https://youtu.be/qpYk6SQEWBE?t=643

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6372837
Good luck dude. Nobody does this. Everyone just eyeballs it. From lots of figure drawing practice, we develop an eye for what's right.

When you speak english you don't autistically calculate the grammar of each word, do you? The same applies to drawing. If you really want to be precise, say, you're drafting out a projection of an architectural space and there's a statue, then you need to start with the front, profile, top, and bottom views, plot out an accurate xyz perspective grid, and slowly plot out where each joint goes. David Chelsea's comic book perspective (which is actually very in depth) and Erik Olson's course are the only resources I know of that teach this.

posts.com:
I am just finishing up Brent Eviston's The Art and Science of Drawing. Before that, I completed Drawing on the Right Side of the Brain. Now that I have a decent exposure to the basics using traditional materials I finally sprang for that iPad i've been eyeing for a couple years now. I got a really good deal on a used 12.9" iPad Pro (2020) and got procreate, but since i'm a complete beginner to digital i was hoping I could follow a course to learn how to use digital tools. It's okay if it goes over the same beginner topics such as form, value, light and shadow, etc since I need to practice all this anyway.

There are so many courses to choose from, after doing a bit of research i've found the following:

- CtrlPaint
- Med's Map
- RossDraws Digital Art Bootcamp
- Digital Painting Fundamentals by Jon Neimeister


There's still a ton I need to practice.

I've never done any Figure Drawing which I do want to learn since I'm very interested in learning character art. But even after the two beginner courses i've completed I still feel like a total beginner in terms of perspective, light, and form and i'm wondering if I need to continue using traditional materials with some other courses that dives into something specific to get better at one of those topics.

Maybe I can slowly do a digital course while also learning something like figure drawing using traditional materials and a different course?


feeling overwhelmed, what do?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6385695
>CtrlPaint
Good but uses a lot of layer-heavy, technical methods and is very Photoshop specific.
>Med's Map
Great course, but I wouldn't recommend it for a complete beginner. Photoshop focused as well.
>RossDraws Digital Art Bootcamp
Only seen a little bit of this myself. Doesn't seem like it's designed for complete beginners, but if you really like his style it should be fine once you've got the basics down.
>Digital Painting Fundamentals by Jon Neimeister
Best course I've seen. Actually teaches you the digital painting fundamentals thoroughly so you can apply it to different software.

If you liked Brent Eviston, you could do his figure drawing course as well. If you think you are not ready yet for figure drawing, going over the fundamentals again in a Procreate course wouldn't hurt.
There are loads of Procreate courses on skillshare/udemy/domestika etc. but the instructors aren't very good. Some YouTube videos on the basics of Procreate might prove more useful. Sinix and Ergojosh should be enough to get you started. Nikolai Lockertsen has two Procreate courses on Schoolism. His first one is for beginners and goes over some fundamentals, you can skip the animation stuff if you are not interested in that. Once you've got Procreate down, the best digital painting tutorials are in Photoshop, so you'll have to learn to adjust for Procreate. I would recommend Jon Neimeister and Med's Maps courses.
With regards to digital vs. traditional, that depends on your goals. If digital painting is you main goal, it's fine to just focus on that. A lot of traditional courses would work fine doing them digitally. If you want to do a mix of both, the skills transfer over so it's fine. As long as you have the time, doing two courses at once is fine too. The fundamentals overlap, so it will actually help. You can split it up, like 1 hours of trad and 1 hour of digital, or 1st day trad and 2nd day digital. Adjust for your preferences and goals.

>If you're ready for it, a figure drawing course, like Brent Eviston's. Trad or digital.
>Med's Map for lots of good digital painting techniques and more fundamentals practice.

posts.com:
>>6385695
Viktor Kalvachev's Schoolism course is an excellent intro for anyone interested in figure drawing.

I personally believe in sticking to trad for a couple of years before trying digital art, but since you already own an iPad watch some basic procreate tutorials on youtube to get used to the UI and reproduce some of your trad exercises on digital to achieve some of the "muscle memory" you'll need later on.


If you never ever touched a digital tool I recommend learning a bit of photo edit on photoshop. Really basic stuff like tutorials on how to change a person's hair color, adjust contrast, clean up an image. It is a low-stakes way to get familiar with digital tools and what they can do for you. I feel it is easier to edit a photo than to draw a whole piece from scratch and THEN try to experiment with digital trickery.

>>6409856
yea but i inherently do not want to create images that are already out there in large quantities. and only those give "good" results. anything more niche inherently has less images and consequently gives shitty results. it's by design, so this cannot be fixed. it's not a bug or a deficit to be filled- it's literally the main feature of machine learning. do you understand that? if you say "but there will be more images that are the exact thing you want to draw", i will no longer want to draw it - precisely because it's overdone at this point.
so it just becomes more attractive to just draw it myself instead, it's easier that way because i have control over the entire image straight away instead, and am free to try combinations of concepts and poses i want, instead of hoping the model incidentally generates the pose/perspective/colors/light situation/environment i actually want.
so why should i care?
despite the rather shady way the machine is trained, i can still see how people who don't draw can have fun and experience their own version of artistic freedom while using it. but to me, it's just a novelty toy and has nothing to do with what i want...

>>6407108
I'm assuming you fags don't care about gainz and just want basic injury prevention.
Buy a resistance band (but with light resistance since you guys are weak af) and do these exercises I'm about to list.
just google the names and watch some youtube tutorials to know how to do them properly.

>Shoulders, because you probably have shit posture
Band Facepulls, Band Pull-Aparts

>Elbows
Band Curls, Band Tricep Extensions

>Wrists
Band Wrist Curls, Band Reverse Curls

>Lower Back
Band Deadlifts, Band Good Mornings

Just do these exercises everyday before you draw.
1 sets for each exercise until failure (with good form) should be more than enough.
Should take 10 minutes max.

That's pretty much everything you need to prevent all the common artist injuries (Wrist, Elbow, Shoulders, Neck, Lower Back)

>>6407108
> Wake up after full 8 hours sleep
> Stretch and lift for 20-30 mins, nothing exhausting, just enough to "feel it"
> Eat breakfast with cat
> Send out any packages from online store sales by short walk to post office
> Come home, Draw
> Lunch, stretch, play with cat again
> Resume draw until sun starts to set
> Take walk while there's still some light
> Watch a movie or show in personal collection (future drawing ideas sometimes come from watching stuff)
> Keep drawing, but at a slower pace while watching
> Finish movie and drawing for the day, play about an hour of video games or jerk off
> Look over drawing one last time before getting ready for bed to see what might need work next day
All this to keep physically and mentally fit.

>>6407108
Gentle stretching for the wrists, neck and back throughout the day, you can find follow along videos easily on youtube that you can even do at your desk. Take walks to move your body and get some fresh air, it's good for your legs, your heart and your mood.

If you have any aches or pains, take a break and try to address it. If you ignore problems when they're still small all that's going to happen is it fucks you up worse long term and you have to rest much much longer to recover. Untreated carpal tunnel can cause permanent dysfunction but fortunately it's less common than tendonitis. Carpal tunnel involves your nerves so if you feel any kind of numbness it's important to see a doctor and to stop what you're doing.

Finally, you can reduce the chance of injury by keeping your hands and wrists warm while you work. You can play with a kneaded eraser, sip hot drinks or just wear something warm on the area. The important thing is just keeping the tendons in a more relaxed state.
